framework.framework_title: A review of a book or film/movie

framework_intro.para: Below is a suggested framework to help you structure your review. There are spaces for you to add your notes and the content of your review.
You can visit the help section to learn more about Oxford iWriter.

step.label: What is the purpose of a review?

commentary.para: The main purpose of a review is to describe and explain the main elements of a book or film (plot, character, themes, etc.) and express a personal opinion about them. The reader should get a clear impression of what the book’s or film’s good and bad points are, and the review should include a recommendation to read the book or see the film or not.
Below is the framework that was used to create this review.
In order to plan the review, the writer decides what to cover in each paragraph and takes notes.
Asking a question is one way to engage the reader.
The writer follows with a personal opinion.
The title and author's name appears here.
Information about the setting and period is also given.

step.label: Talking about the plot and characters

commentary.para: It is usual to use the present tense to describe the story.
Including information on the style of writing can be helpful.
Express your opinion and give reasons to support it.
You can restate your opinion of the book/film as a recommendation to read/see it or not read/see it.
The writer uses key language for reviews.
Linking words aid organization and clearly link your ideas.

checklist.point: Read or re-read the book and make notes on the plot, the characters, the way the book is written, and your opinion of it.
Think about questions your reader might have
When you have made notes, decide on the order in which you wish to present the information and organize your notes, using the framework as a guide.
Use appropriate words and phrases to begin and end.
Use appropriate words and phrases to describe plot and characters.
Find a range of adjectives to use to describe the book, plot and characters.
Use your dictionary to help you find synonyms of words such as 'book' or 'story'.
When you have organized your notes into the framework, write your review, following this structure.
Remember that the person who reads your review has NOT read the book.
Try to write about both positive and negative aspects of the book.
Does the introduction give the title of the book and the author?
Does the introduction give general information about the setting, period, etc.?
Does the body of the review discuss the plot and the characters?
Have I included information about the way the book is written?
Does the conclusion give my opinion?
Have I used a variety of adjectives and phrases to describe the book?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar and spelling?

para.strong: A review of Wuthering Heights by Emily Brontë

paragraph.name: Introduction
paragraph.desc: General information and comments about the book/film
paragraph.tip: TIP Asking a question is one way to engage the reader. Or you could start with a personal opinion. The title of the book/film, and for book reviews the author's name, should appear here. Information about the setting and era can be useful too.

notes.para: Love story or gothic story? Blend of both; written in 1847; family saga
Violent emotions: desire, hate, revenge, regret. Wild Yorkshire moors reflect this.

content.para: Is it a darkly passionate tale of love? Or should we call it a highly original gothic story? The classic novel 'Wuthering Heights' by Emily Brontë is, in my opinion, a unique and gripping blend of these genres. Written in 1847, it is an epicfamily saga full of desire, hate, revenge and regret, focusing on the main characters of Heathcliff and Catherine. The atmospheric setting of the wild Yorkshire moors cleverly mirrors these violent emotions.

Is it a darkly passionate tale of love? Or should we call it a highly original gothic story? The classic novel 'Wuthering Heights' by Emily Brontë is, in my opinion, a unique and gripping blend of these genres. Written in 1847, it is an epic family saga full of desire, hate, revenge and regret, focusing on the main characters of Heathcliff and Catherine. The atmospheric setting of the wild Yorkshire moors cleverly mirrors these violent emotions.

paragraph.name: Plot
paragraph.desc: A brief summary of what happens.
paragraph.tip: TIP It is usual to use the present tense to describe the story. You can use more than one paragraph for each part of your review.

notes.para: Story: Catherine's father adopts Heathcliff. Her brother, Hindley, is jealous. She falls in love with Heathcliff. Father dies and Hindley makes Heathcliff be a servant. Catherine marries Edgar Linton—closer in class and position in society. Leads to tragedy.

content.para: When Catherine's father adopts the starving orphan boy Heathcliff, Catherine's brother Hindley feels deeply hurt and resentful. She, on the other hand, develops an immensely strong bond with Heathcliff, which becomes an all-consuming love. Upon her father's death, Hindley becomes the head of the family and forces Heathcliff to assume the position of a servant. Despite loving Heathcliff, Catherine chooses to marry Edgar Linton, who is closer to her class and position in society. It is this decision which leads to heartbreak and tragedy, not only for them but for many others.

paragraph.name: Characters
paragraph.desc: Briefly describe and comment on the main characters.

notes.para: Heathcliff: anti-hero—rough manners, lack of control. Catherine has flaws. Readers empathize with them both.
Book brilliant because true to life. Readers horrified by behaviour of Catherine and Heathcliff but don't hate them because the reasons for their actions are clear.

content.para: Heathcliff could be described as an anti-hero with his rough manners and lack of control. Likewise, Catherine displays many flaws but the reader can still empathize with these characters. In fact, this is the main reason why I believe this novel is so brilliant. It rings with truth. The reader may be horrified at the way that Heathcliff and Catherine behave, and yet, at the same time, the writer ensures we never hate them because the reasons for their actions are crystal clear.

paragraph.name: Other information
paragraph.desc: Anything else important that you want to say about the book (e.g. style of writing, literary devices) or film.

notes.para: Book has narrator—Ellen Dean, a servant. Useful because holds the plot together.
Book is not an easy read—dense description; dialogue in dialect—can be difficult to understand.

content.para: The main part of the book relies on a narrator, Ellen Dean, who is a servant at Wuthering Heights and I think that this is a useful device which holds the complex plot together. However, Wuthering Heights is not what I would call an 'easy read'. There is dense description and some of the dialogue is written in dialect, which can be difficult to follow.

paragraph.name: Conclusion
paragraph.tip: TIP You can restate your opinion of the book/film as a recommendation to read/see it or not read/see it.

content.para: Nevertheless, I persevered and, all in all, can highly recommend Wuthering Heights. I challenge you to remain unmoved after reading this exceptional book .
